action_results.action: "Brother, brother, can you tell me another story?"
action_results.result:
“Brother, brother, can you tell me another story?” 




The voice belonged to a young girl who had yet to finish her baptism. A heap of blankets covered her body, leaving only her face exposed. Her eyes sparkled under the warm glow of the hearth’s fire. The winter blizzards that raged outside their cozy abode made the bolts and screws of their dangly door rattle. Still, the howling winds didn’t faze the brother as much. Heavy snowfall like this was a common occurrence in the city. He peeked outside the tiny hole of the door. It seemed that night had already settled in as he saw the last slivers of the sun touch the rooftops of the opposite street. After the sixth bell, his father and mother would come home from work. 




He ignored his little sister’s pleads. There was still much to do before their arrival. The fire needed to be watched over, the winter handiwork of the day had to be finished and he needed to start chopping the vegetables for the stew. He wanted to start finishing up these tasks when he was released at the fifth bell, but the foreman didn’t let him go home early. Apparently the carpentry workshop had yet to finish the last-minute orders of the merchant that passed through a week ago.




“The story.”




His little sister sure was persistent. He sighed and knelt down.




“And your basket weaving?”




She furrowed her brows before scurrying to the storage room. When she came back a crudely made basket was placed in his hands. He tugged at it to see if it held up together. To his surprise, it seemed to be sturdy enough to sell for one Fistel coin. He sighed. 




“Fine, put out the lamp before we waste anymore oil.”




At least she listened this time. When their parents were at home, she would be the sweetest little ray of sunshine. Only he knew how much of a headache she could be. She ignored his exasperated sighs and scooted over where he sat. The fire behind them warmed their backs.




“This time it will be a quick one, so listen carefully.” He said. 




His finger pointed straight at her nose. He quickly continued in an attempt to avoid her voicing her protests. It was better to keep her mouth shut from the very beginning lest he wanted her to interrupt him constantly.




“This is the story of the last king.”




She tilted her head. “Last king? Do you mean-”




“Yeah, it’s the one they tell you during your baptism.” He cleared his throat.




“Can you not tell me one of mum’s stories?”




He sent a glare straight to her. 




“You asked me right?”




“Fine, tell me.”




At last he could begin.

action_results.action: “So Imagine that you were the last king named uhh.. what was his name again….ah yeah…Henrik!”
action_results.result:
The study was as chilly as the snow covered plains outside the palace. Still, you heard the thundering vibrations of the cannons and firearms that were fired off by your guards. The city was now in full anarchy for several days now. You didn’t want to know how many have perished as you mulled over the stack of paper work. Not many were allowed to go in your room, especially in grave times like these. 




Last week there had been a cook that had sprinkled some poison in your tea and in the more distant past you remembered that you had to relieve some of your guards from their duty after a security breach. Thus, only two people were now in the study beside you. Your most trusted guard Eckhart rested his back against the door. All color had drained from his face, leaving behind only a pasty complexion and dark blue circles under his eyes. His hands gripped tightly to his rifle. Your advisor Fulke who stood next to your desk was not in a much better shape as he tried to calm down his tremor. After that incident from last week, he refused to eat more than a few biscuits. 




You turned to Fulke after you had read the last letters and drily asked him. “How should we proceed?”




His eyes widened while he covered his mouth. He lightly shook his head before averting his gaze.




“We have several options, but ultimately they have to be made before the sun rises. The insurrectionists’ representatives will arrive at dawn. I myself…”




In other words, he wanted to say that the choice was up to you to make. The fate of this nation lied solely in your hands. It would be too much of a burden to place it on a single advisor, no matter how competent he may be. 




You then shifted your eyes to Eckhart who had until now chosen to remain silent. 




“Have you read their demands too?”




He curtly nodded. His words were spoken softer than whispers. “A democracy, a ruler chosen not by the decree of the gods. I don’t know what has befallen those souls. Utter heresy.”




Fulke lowered his eyes to mask his grimace at Eckhart’s remark. “There’s a lot of public support for such ideas as far as my assistants have told me whenever they visit the parlor rooms. It would be difficult to quell these concepts once they have propagated under the populace. Perhaps a peaceful solution may be more effective.”




A vein bulged out of Eckhart’s head. His stony face shifted into something more resembling a glare. 




“Do you wish for the gods to strike us down?” He said. “I didn’t know that you have the soft hands of a coward, Fulke.”




“We are not talking about a spar or the outcome of a physical brawl, but the life of our liege.”




Fulke put extra emphasis on the last words as his eyes narrowed. In the corner of your eyes you already could see Eckhart’s hands balling into fists to measure the time needed to reach Fulke's nose. Tension in the room thickened with each passing second. 

Just before Eckhart reached out to Fulke, you slammed your hand on your desk. Both were visibly startled by your lowered voice. 




“You two, leave.” You said. “I will give you my answer before dawn.”




As a trained guard would do, Eckhart immediately left without protest though he shot a worrying glance at you before he closed the door to wait outside. Fulke expressed more of his reluctance, but one more nod from you had convinced him to leave you alone for now. 




As their presence left the room, you slumped against your chair. So it had all come down to this very moment? Although your father had warned you about many things like the different noble factions vying for the royal family’s favor, the increased tension in the borders shared with Essenschaft or the high bishop whose wrath must not be gained. Despite your father's vast knowledge and the various documents in the palace’s library, there was no one right answer you could think of. 




While the candle’s light grew ever brighter under the setting sun, your thoughts slowly wandered off to the past as you desperately tried to search for the path you could walk on.

action_results.action: Your first time leading a group
action_results.result:
You peered through the window. The budding leaves and flowers of the trees and bushes of the courtyard all showed the end of the cold winter and the beginning of the new year. The gods’ yearly awakening and arrival to the earthly realm to lavish the lands with fruitful blessings, always marked the return of spring. 




You yourself were too brimming with excitement, knowing that this was the first time you were allowed to attend a social gathering. You were a little disappointed that this one was not organized by your parents, but by your uncle, the army's commander. 




Your milk brother Eckhart had attended several last year and the year before after his social debut and had bragged about the sweets they served during these tea parties. He also paraded around the brooch and embroidered cape his mother had given him for his baptism as if his family crest was so much more special than the other ones. You made sure to remind him every time that your parents will give you an even better one, but then Eckhart brought up the sweets again. In a fit of jealousy you begged your nannies to also let you participate in these tea parties, but they all said you had to wait until you had been baptized. 




You puffed out your chest, temporarily forgoing any manners your caretakers had taught you and ran out of your room, traversed through several hallways to almost enter the courtyard before you were pulled aside by none other than Eckhart. It was odd to see his hair all slicked up and to see him wearing his tailed coat, but the familiar short sword that was slung against his hips calmed your nerves.




His panicked expression quickly turned sour as he started to glare at you. In his still high-pitched voice that was perhaps a little too loud for your taste, he shouted.




“Think a little more.”




It was strange coming from a muscle head like Eckhart. Seeing that even your wet nurse had complained about his empty head and reluctance to put what little he had into proper use during his studies, you couldn’t help but be slightly stunned as he lectured you about the dangers of walking without any retainers and the supposed social blunder you almost made by not letting Eckhart accompany you. 




He was already acting so weird during your baptism ceremony when he started to not call you by your given name in public anymore. The long oath he swore to you made you even more uncomfortable the longer you thought about it. You could only imagine Eckhart’s grueling study sessions with your wet nurse.




Most of this information Eckhart had blabbered to you went one ear in and one ear out. You knew he was right, but a stubborn side of you didn’t want him to know that. Thus, you nodded halfheartedly as he insisted on walking behind you. It was sometimes quite difficult to fathom that Eckart, the one who had been your playmate ever since you were born and who was only two years older than you, was now assigned as your apprentice guard. 




When you arrived at the gathering, you couldn’t help but freeze up after you saw so many eyes paying attention to every breath you took. Although you could vaguely remember some of their faces as they had also witnessed your baptism, you were utterly unfamiliar with the majority of the nobles who lined up to greet you one by one. At first the adults from the higher duchies stepped forward, followed by the lower ranked ones. After you had sent off the last baron, it was the children’s turn. Boys and girls, some taller and some even smaller than you, lowered their heads before you. Eckhart didn’t seem to be that bothered by the avalanche of new faces. His gaze had wandered off to the duke of Cassisheit and his daughter. 






Just as your smile wavered, Eckhart prodded your sides. 




“Think about the sweets.” He mouthed at you. 




With his very convincing words in mind, you plastered a polite smile on your face as you finished your greetings. However, the sweets were not yet within your grasp. A band of other children forced you to forfeit your quest for now. Their twinkling eyes looked at you while they gripped tightly to their wooden swords. Although you had every authority to refuse, Eckhart shot you a menacing smile while his grip on your shoulder tightened. 




“The prince is elated to give his permission for this small bout.”




You glanced back at him. He really did put words in your mouth. When you were about to protest, he gave you a look that made you swallow your thoughts all too readily. Your parents did emphasize that a person from your standing needed to assert their presence one way or the other, but you weren’t sure that a sparring match was the proper way to do so. You weren’t really afraid of Eckhart losing his honor in a humiliating defeat, but his participation would leave you without any guards. You weren’t exactly keen to earn the wrath of your caretakers. While you mulled over the underlying benefits of letting Eckhart spar, the boy himself continued to stare intensely in the direction of the duke of Cassisheit. 




After some pondering you sighed in your head. Whenever Eckhart had that glimmer in his eyes, you knew that he wouldn’t be able to hold back. Even if you tried to stop him, he would sulk about it for at least a day or two. 




You locked your eyes on the children you will surely grow more familiar with in the upcoming years. They were the future dukes, marquises, earls, viscounts and barons. Your father did say that you ought to be polite to them. He did tell you the reason, but you forgot the very day he had told you. It was too much of a headache to remember. You hadn’t bothered to ask Eckhart, because he too would probably not know. 




“My trusted retainer will be sent out with my blessing.” You said.  




Eckhart relinquished his grip and ran to the open patch of ground at the upper right corner of the courtyard beyond the small patios where the adults were gathered. 




Low and behold, the first challenger, a boy, one year his senior and carrying the emblem of Cassisheit, was defeated within a few moves. In the beginning he may have had the upper hand and the sand throwing was indeed interesting to see, but Eckhart’s raw talent and trained skill was not something to take lightly. Unlike the group of children gathered around the sparring pair, his eyes were trained on the duke of Cassisheit. 




You tilted your head. Was he so eager to curry the duke’s favor despite him being your retainer?




After you announced the Eckhart’s victory, the next challenger had arrived. It was a boy about your age. Like the other children, his family crest was embroidered on his cape, but you couldn’t exactly place the name to any family you knew of. Looking at the widened eyes of the other children, you would guess that his choice to participate was a rather unconventional one. The most noticeable physical feature he had were his long gangly limbs. He lowered his head while he stuttered out the following words. 




“Please, I would like to try too.” 




Eckhart’s eyes narrowed the moment he saw the embroidered crest. A certain coldness you had never seen before flitted through his eyes. He huffed before he beckoned the boy to step into the makeshift arena. 




He casually walked to his side of the circle and took on a stance you had seen before. All of a sudden his face shifted into a sneer. You then quickly shifted your attention to the new challenger, who was still fumbling around with his coat pockets. 




“Can we use everything within our disposal?” He timidly asked Eckhart.




Eckhart then glanced at you as he waited for your final verdict. 




“Everything except the help of other people.” You hurriedly added. “Of course the use of bladed weapons and other tools which cause blood to spill or permanently maim the opponent are strictly forbidden.” 




The challenger gave you a timid smile and settled on his respective side of the arena. However, he still chose to stand around doing nothing without any apparent need to take up a stance or to ready an attack. Just as you were about to cringe at the sight of the upcoming slaughter, the quick turn of events made you gasp out of surprise. 




Seeing that the boy was planning on doing absolutely nothing, Eckhart charged head on. The moment his sword was about to strike the boy’s chest, a bright flash of light shot out of the challenger’s hand. During this small time span of weakness and confusion, the boy slammed his wooden sword right at the family’s jewels. Soon you heard Eckhart’s pained grunt after he fell on the ground in a fetal position. 




The challenger’s cheeks were fully flushed despite the cool spring weather. In his hand shimmered a mirror’s shard against the bright sunlight. You rubbed your eyes to make sure that this sight was not a mere mirage. 




Indeed, the boy had won. 




Just as the others were about to slowly clap for his victory, Eckhart shot up, his eyes filled with rage. He kicked the boy on his shins repeatedly till the young challenger fell over. The boy tried to crawl away, but Eckhart grasped his hair to prevent his escape. You tilted your head after witnessing this peculiar event.




“Eckhart, what is the meaning of this? The bout has ended if I’m correct.”




“He cheated.” Eckhart spit these words out with fervor. “He has a lot of nerve for the son of a baron’s second wife.”




You carefully nodded and considered your next actions. Never in your life had you thought that a tea party would be such a headache. You only wanted to devour these sweets that were being displayed on the patios. Your caretakers never allowed you to indulge in them too much for fear of your health, but you could almost hear these crumbly butter cookies calling for you to taste them.

action_results.action: Let Eckhart strike the boy for his insolence.
action_results.result:
Standings and knowing where one’s place was, were one of the most crucial things in noble society. You knew exactly what Eckhart meant to say in his own roundabout way. You tilted your head. 




If the boy was also the son of a duke’s first wife like Eckhart, he would be applauded for his remarkable creative way of thinking. It was too bad that he was born of such a poor house. One had to know when to show your cards and when to hold back against a stronger foe. The boy should have never been allowed to participate in the first place and even if he got the opponent’s permission, defeat was the only option to avoid the other noble’s wrath. Alas, a dog eat dog world it was.




There was a reason why traditions were traditions in the first place. 




You then looked at the adults who had all turned their attention to the makeshift arena. Apparently they too had noticed Eckhart’s all too screeching scream. In the back of your mind you were relieved that your parents had been absent during this gathering. You spotted your uncle in the crowd who was donning a satisfied smirk while raising his brows. If you could say some words to butter him up, he might keep his mouth shut during his reports. Your father’s and mother’s lectures were not the most pleasant experience you could think of.




In the back of the crowd you could see the blood drained face of a nobleman whose cape carried the same embroidered family crest and color as the challenger. Based on his age, you guessed that this was probably the boy’s father. His eyes were briefly locked into yours while he silently pleaded for your mercy. His son had quite a will of his own. 




You shrugged and turned back to the two duelists.




“Eckhart, please continue where you have left off.” You said while you put your hand on your cheek. 




Eckhart’s eyes twinkled with glee. He kicked the boy black and blue ignoring his tears and desperate pleas. After he was done, the baron’s son could barely move. Some of the spectators tried to reach out, but quickly aborted their efforts when you glared at them. It would be foolish of them to intervene, as this action would go against your expressed orders. You didn’t want to take care of another incident on the same day. If this went on like this, you would never be able to eat your sweets.




A few of them looked at you in horror as if you were the one who had given such a cruel order. Well, it was technically you, because Eckhart was under your authority, but that didn’t matter to you in the slightest. You crossed your arms. 




It was Eckhart’s fault for being such a meathead. 




Still you let Eckhart have his fun for a while. It had taken a surprisingly long time till he was fully satisfied. You nodded while you watched on. Perhaps this would be useful to keep in mind in the future. You placed your hand on your cheek after you heard another whimper coming from the boy. It would be a smart idea to report Eckhart’s remarkable stamina to your father on your next meeting. 




At last, when the boy stopped screaming, Eckhart ceased his attacks. He slumped backwards and gave you a satisfied smile. That bright expression on his face lasted for a few precious moments but as soon as you gave him that broad smile similar to the one your wet nurse always gave to you both whenever you two caused any sort of trouble, he winced. 




Your smile widened as you slowly cocked your head to your left. Eckhart knew what was waiting ahead of him in due time. 

You then walked to the spot where the boy was lying on his back. It was almost pitiful to see him like this. To award him for his odd bravery while overlooking his suicidal stupidity, you fished out your handkerchief to dab away the blood trickling out of the corner of his mouth. His swollen eyes widened for a moment as you leant forward. Under the cover of the rumbling crowd, you managed to slip in a few words to him. He was lucky that he was not of age yet.




“Hmm.. you have caught my attention, but favor is hard to earn.”




You then beckoned Eckhart to join your side as you made way to the patio. Your mouth salivated when you smelt the honey coated cookies.

action_results.action: Scold Eckhart for harming the boy after his rightful win.
action_results.result:
You weren’t necessarily keen on violence and the boy hadn’t broken any of the rules you had placed. There was a strange admiration you had for his unique way to approach problems. Looking at his thin arms and legs, Eckhart could have easily overpowered him if one were to only look at physical strength. Although Eckhart did have a point regarding the gap between their social standings, he was the one who had accepted the boy’s challenge. On top of that, he acted outside of your direct orders and against your own wishes.




Didn’t he know that this beating would only deplete your precious time where you could have eaten those delectable sweets? Eckhart really had done this for his own self-interest and to your dismay, his etiquette training sadly hadn't taught him how to be level-headed. 




You then looked at the adults who had all turned their attention to the makeshift arena. Apparently they too had noticed Eckhart’s all too screeching scream. In the back of your mind you were relieved that your parents had been absent during this gathering. You spotted your uncle in the crowd who was donning a satisfied smirk while raising his brows. If you could say some words to butter him up, he might keep his mouth shut during his reports. Your father’s and mother’s lectures were not the most pleasant experience you could think of.




In the back of the crowd you could see the blood drained face of a nobleman whose cape carried the same embroidered family crest and color as the challenger. Based on his age, you guessed that this was probably the boy’s father. His eyes were briefly locked into yours while he silently pleaded for your mercy. If you could have a private conversation with the man, you would have complimented his son for his remarkable wit. 




You gave him a curt nod before you turned back at the two duelists. 




“Eckhart, please release the winner of the bout immediately.”




Eckhart’s eyes lit up in anger. You could almost see him going on another rampage, but luckily he stopped after your eyes narrowed to give him one final warning. If it was in a more private setting, you would have simply yelled at him and entered into a scuffle or two, but you weren’t inside your quarters. Your father did say that punishment was necessary to discipline your retainers, but it always felt like such a chore to you. 




Tension was released when Eckhart at last dropped his wooden sword and returned to your side. There will be no agonizing knot in your stomach when all this was over. A sudden joy wafted over you as you realized you could eat all those sweets peacefully without any lingering guilt.




The groan of the boy brought you back to reality before you got too ahead of yourself. You tilted your head as you watched the boy slowly stand up. What would be a proper reward? After witnessing his rather rash actions, it was very apparent to you that there were some underlying motives here.




“Congratulations for your outstanding victory. It seems that my guard’s training has been lacking in some areas.” 

“Thank you ever so much, your royal highness.” 




There were still some thin tremors in his voice. You gave him a thin smile before you closed the distance to slip your handkerchief into his breast pocket. Using the crowd’s turmoil in your favor, you softly whispered to him the following words. 




“Hmm.. you have caught my attention, but favor is hard to earn. I do see a future. It appears that new ways of thinking are always needed in the kingdom.”




You and Eckhart then made your way to the patio, leaving the boy behind. You gave his supposed father a curt nod to allow him to attend his son, before you bit into one of the honey coated cookies. Their sweetness was everything you had craved for. The feeling of the sugar clumps melting on your tongue was something truly magical. 




Just as you were about to devour another cookie, you saw in the corner of your eyes the grateful smiles of two family members.


This warmth they shared, it felt quite a sight to behold.

action_results.action: Your first time talking with your tutor
action_results.result:
Your baptism seemed like such a long time ago and your first tea party too. Although you had initially been excited about the increased amount of people you were allowed to meet and especially the food they introduced to you, the novelty did wore off all too quickly. It was the same feeling you had with your tutors. Alas, you wished you were seven again, but even the gods couldn’t reverse the deeds of the time weaver. These thirteen years couldn’t easily be reversed.




Your fingers lightly tapped on the desk. You heard a soft thud that could only come from Eckhart slamming his face on the wall. The summer heat and the stuffy room would probably be suffocating for such a hot headed individual like Eckhart, but you had a nagging feeling that this wasn’t the sole reason. If you recalled correctly, Eckhart had been this way ever since his coming of age ceremony last spring. Since that day he had ceased to use his brain for anything useful. At least he had stopped talking about every minutia of the duchy of Cassisheit. 




Your wet nurse had once said to you that all of his nutrients went to his height, to which you reluctantly had to agree on. It was a miracle that he had managed to learn court etiquette at all or learnt how to read and write though his handwriting was admittedly still abysmal. If he would be so kind to offer some of this growth to you, you would have forgiven him for the hours of headaches you had to endure to parse out his scribbles that were supposed to resemble reports. 




It wasn’t only Eckhart who was in a rather foul mood, you also couldn’t help but purse your lips as you waited for your tutor to come. In the past couple of weeks your parents were more busy than ever. After your baptism, you were graced with one shared meal every two days, but now all of your communication had to be done with letters. You played with the yellow brooch pinned on your cape. The gem placed inside its golden arches glimmered under the dim sunlight. The warmth of your hand heated the cold metal. You could almost feel two arms wrapped around you.




Then you heard another loud thud followed by Eckart’s whines. Although his voice had caught up with his growth spurt, it was still as loud as ever. His language did turn quite crude at the end too. 




“It was finished, even learnt the stupid long god names, mum, you liar. University, why, why?”




You two were soon interrupted by the turn of the doorknob and a soft knock. After giving Eckhart one more tired glance you gestured at him to open the door. 




At last, the tutor had arrived. The sharp features on his face had softened with his age. Stray strands of his otherwise neatly slicked back hair, only made you more aware how much of a hurry these two were. Next to him stood a young boy around your age. His face seemed kind of familiar to you. Still, that didn’t say a lot. As you had met so many people that you couldn’t be bothered to know every noble’s name let alone their children, you assumed that he would be some baron’s child you had greeted during the many tea parties you had participated in.




“Forgive me, your royal highness. We had some delays during our journey here.” The tutor said. 




He glared at the boy next to him who shrunk under his eyes. The boy stepped forward and bowed. 




“I’m Fulke, Viscount Grunnenberg’s assistant.”




You couldn’t help but brighten your smile. Your wet nurse did inform you that Eckhart will soon have to prepare for the royal academy. An extra watchful eye would help him not to slack off. Although his arrival wasn’t a surprise, you had expected this assistant to look more mature. The letter had told you that he would be a little older than Eckhart. 




“Eckhart will surely get along with you. He was also looking forward to this meeting and was quite eager to learn more about our country’s illustrious history.” You said. “A lot of words of praise were spoken about you two.”




Fulke was now definitely hiding behind the tutor while his eyes kept quivering. You tilted your head. Perhaps a little too forceful? Eckhart didn’t seem that bothered with what you had said as he was too busy longingly looking at the window. 




The tutor coughed and went to take his seat next to your desk. Soon, the contents of his bag were displayed in front of you. An overflowing pile of papers and books were thrown almost haphazardly on your desk.




“I was notified that you are already aware of the origin story of our nation and our patron gods?”




“Ah yes, the eternal four gods, Lentetulp, Zummerin, Herafst and Schneeuwerik and the time weaver.”




The tutor’s eyes glimmered when you said their names without any hesitation. You could already see that he was testing your knowledge here. It would be quite amusing to see him shift his attention to Eckhart, but seeing that your poor guard had quite a rough time and was doing these puppy-dog eyes at you, you will take the limelight this time. 




“In another realm beyond our understanding where life was eternal and ever flowing, the time weaver remained the supreme god. He was a stern, but fair ruler of the land. However, his children, the eternal gods who were birthed out of his threads rebelled against him to overtake the throne. One fateful day, the four decided to poison the time weaver so that no more threads will be spun, but their attempt had failed.” 




“Out of anger, the time weaver sent these four children to the empty earthly realm to repent for their sins. He ordered them to fill the realm with the same splendor and life as the realm of the gods. If they succeeded, they will be allowed to come back home. So Lentetulp filled the world with blossoming flowers and animal life, Zummerin granted the trees with plenty of fruit, Herafst made the leaves ever so colorful and Schneeuwerik gave birth to the first humans.”




“After Herafst’s blessings were given, the time weaver had called them home. The moment they followed his order, the earthly realm crumbled into ruin with deadly cold blizzards raging through the lands. Schneeuwerik, the youngest sibling and the apple of her father’s eyes, begged the time weaver to let them return as she alone had grown quite fond of the earthly realm. The time weaver had to keep his word to his other three children, but he did want to grant her wish. Thus out of his love for Schneeuwerik, he unwound his threads again to reverse time.”




“And so the seasons were born. Every time Herafst had finished her blessings, the time weaver unwound his thread to go back in time once again. The only thread that remained untouched was the thread of life that he had bestowed to the gentle and beautiful Schneeuwerik, the one that he had loved so dearly.”




Once the story was finished you looked straight at the tutor. He stroke his chin with a neutral expression. Soon he rummaged through his papers to fish out a crudely drawn family tree and map. You closed your eyes and quickly rattled off the increasingly elaborate titles and names of your predecessors. There were about fifty of them of which the last ten’s names and deeds were memorized by you last summer. 




Still, your self-study didn’t seem to have impressed your tutor all that much. All he did was lean back to his chair while casually stating the following.  




“If you had learnt this much, these documents and books will not be useful to your royal highness.”




Eckhart shot up and glared at the man. Before he could open his mouth you raised your hand. This will certainly be a pleasant conversation or at least an interesting one.




“No one except us will hear the words spoken in this room.”




The tutor ‘s lips curled up in a calculating smile. It carried the same glint your parents always showed during their respective social gatherings. 




“I do wonder where the power of a ruler lies, how his authority is justified.” He said. 




You glanced at Eckhart who was impatiently waiting for his turn to speak. It couldn’t hurt to let him answer this question for once. It would help him get some of his confidence back. 




“Of course it is because of Schneeuwerik’s thread. She had put the first piece in the heart of the first king of this nation and put her trust into his children. The king’s will is the gods’ will.”




A small smile as praise from you was enough for Eckhart to puff out his chest. The tutor nodded.




“That is indeed what I ought to teach you.” He then looked at Fulke who had all this time been hiding in the far corner of the room. Drops of sweat had already stained his cravat. “I do recall that my lovely assistant had heard of other answers outside the castle’s premises.”




Fulke lowered his head and folded his arms as if to cradle himself.




“Schneeuwerik does not extend her hand unconditionally. To keep her thread, one has to take care of the realm and the lives she held so dearly. Like what happened with the four gods and the time weaver, this grace could easily be taken away.” He said.


“Master Grunnenberg, is this satisfactory?”






The tutor didn’t spare him a single look. The whole time he was focused on you. 




“Tell me, what will your answer be?”

action_results.action: “The ruler is granted his power by the divine right.”

Was this really a topic one had to discuss? Every noble had learnt this tale for this exact reason. It was part of their curriculum and one of the first stories you had been taught, at least in its simplified form. Even someone who loathed to study like Eckhart knew it by heart. A person was either born to be a ruler and granted Schneeuwerik’s affection or they had to serve under the ruler himself.


That was the way of life.




“Fulke’s answer appears to be quite unorthodox. His environment must be very different from the castle.” You said.




The tutor stroke his chin. He didn’t seem very bothered. 




“My students all like to gather all kinds of information from various sources. Please forgive my student’s impudence.”




“That’s interesting.”




After hearing your words Fulke shrunk back even more. You couldn’t help but pity the boy a little. He must be thinking how he had earned your or his master’s ire. As far as you knew, apprehending him would only touch the threads, but it will not cut it. If you could keep him closer, information will be easier to spin out of him. No dissidents were allowed to exist, but patience was the key to such affairs.




“Teacher, could you show Fulke’s handwriting to us?” You asked. 




The tutor pointed at the small stack of bound papers in the upper right corner of your desk. With one glance, you had made your decision final. 




“It is indeed very pleasing to the eye.” You smiled at the tutor and Eckhart. “Could you two leave the room for a moment? There is a message about to be passed to your assistant.”




You patiently waited for them to obey your command. On his way out Eckhart gave you a puzzled look to which you shrugged. If he guarded your door, then it would be no problem at all in your opinion. You will explain it to him later when his shift was done. 

Now all the people who were left was you and Fulke who was now almost trembling under your gaze. It will be better to be as direct as possible with him.  




“Look, I know that you are not the assistant Viscount Grunnenberg had planned to bring. What is your reason for meeting me? I do admit that you have a lot of nerve for someone of your standing.” You asked while you dropped your polite smile. “Is it to get my father’s favor, hmm?"




“I-I Have. I-“




You sighed and said. “Come on, spit it out.”




“I want to serve you.”




What was that? You blinked. Did he really say that? You blinked again before you regained your composure. 




“Why?”




Fulke averted eyes while color crept to his cheeks. He answered shyly. “To protect the person important to me.”




So you had indeed guessed it right. He did pull of this stunt to protect his mother, father or his siblings. Maybe a noble of higher standing had terrorized his family for a while and now he sought your protection. However, this was quite an unconventional approach. Couldn’t he simply ask a duke of a high ranking duchy for help or something instead of you?




Well, you will find out soon enough if you take him under your wing.




“I wanted to ask you if you would be ever so willing to brush up Eckhart’s way of words, but perhaps I could ask permission for you to be my personal retainer. However, that decision will depend on your other qualities and talents.” You said. “To go through such lengths for your family is indeed admirable.”




All of a sudden every single trace of nervousness or fear melted away from Fulke’s face as if Schneeuwerik had secretly blessed him herself. At last he met your eyes with a full determined look. 




“Gathering information is my specialty.”




This was getting quite fun. You leant forward. “Then tell me something I do not know.”




“The reason for your guard’s lowered mood is because his Schneeuwerik had refused to accept his life thread.” 




You blinked. “Say that again?”




“It is the daughter of the duke of Cassisheit.” He said. 




You stood up and marched to the door. Before you opened it, you turned back to Fulke. 




“If this nonsense what you’re talking about is true, I promise with the time weaver as my guard that you will be my personal retainer.” You then lowered your voice. “If I find out that you only possess a vivid imagination and the skill of trickery, you know what I will do with your future.”




Fulke’s face paled slightly. It was fascinating that he could be frightened this easily. He must have been beaten up quite a bit when he was little. Well, you still wanted to keep him close to you no matter what will happen next, but he didn’t have to know that small detail yet.




You quickly pulled Eckhart aside and whispered in his ear. 




“Is Fransisca your Schneeuwerik?” 




His cheeks reddened as he tried to find his words. You tilted your head. So Fulke’s information was indeed hogwash. It should be very obvious to you now. Last time you had spoken with Eckhart, he had all too easily expressed his disgust towards the fairer sex. All of a sudden he knitted his brows and closed his eyes so tightly as if he wanted to squeeze the words right out of him.




“Yes, she is.”




You blinked. Well, you should write your parents a letter then. Since viscount Grunnenberg had claimed to not be able to teach you anything worthwhile and was awfully late on top of that, perhaps you should also ask for another tutor.

Although you weren’t absolutely sure about Fulke’s theory, it was nevertheless interesting enough for you to want to keep this conversation going and entertain them for the time being. The moment you had expressed you interest, Eckhart looked at you with his brows so raised up that they could almost touch his hairline. 




“It is curious how one would arrive at such an conclusion.” You said. “Who might this person be?”




The tutor clapped his hands together. A carefree smile shimmered under his pursed lips.




“There are many who had exchanged these thoughts. The divine right was not the sole factor how one could determine a suitable ruler. Sometimes a person who is in possession of the thread may not be able to wield it effectively.”




You were now absolutely certain that the main promoter of these ideas was the viscount and that Fulke was roped into his schemes. If they were talking to any other person, this conversation may have not ended this well. They were really playing with fire here. Well, now that they had displayed such a huge amount of courage to say this to a member of the royal family, you had the desire to know more.




“So there must be other qualities a king must have? Would it be fair to assume that he ought to mirror the time weaver?”  




“We humans will never be able to find a perfect candidate with all the knowledge in the world while still keeping his compassion. However, with the strength of many, the least worse decisions are easier to find.” 




“Do you mean that the rulers should be everyone, from the lowest peasant to the highest ranking dukes?”




“Every opinion is valuable according to this viewpoint.” He said while his eyes kept twinkling. “I can return another time to elaborate more on it.”




You shook your head. This wasn’t something you could report back to your parents. Your eyes then shifted to Fulke. As Fulke continued to cower in fear, you slowly curled your lips. That might be a good solution. 




“Teacher, could you show Fulke’s handwriting to us?” You asked. 




The tutor pointed at the small stack of bound papers in the upper right corner of your desk. With one glance, you had made your decision final. 




“It is indeed very pleasing to the eye.” You broadened your smile while still keeping your eyes on Fulke. “Would you be ever so willing to brush up Eckhart’s way of words?”




Eckhart gave you a panicked look in return. You raised your brows and subsequently gave a slight nod to permit him to join the conversation. The moment you did so, his bellowing voice was back. 




“He is younger than me and of lower rank too. Why does he have to teach me? I can do things fine myself your royal highness.”

Sweet sweet Eckart, in one single line, he had already made one false statement out of three and he wouldn’t even know which one. At least he got his fire back, even if it was probably only for this short moment. 




Now he had even caused the whimpering Fulke to press his back against the wall. The first fleeting thought that had crossed you mind was that Fulke was probably bullied by other children in the past. That assumption also fitted in quite well with your theory that he was the second or third son of a low ranking baron.




It was your duty as the person with the highest authority to put a stop to this blossoming animosity between these two. It would be better for your own sanity if they got along immediately, but the  strings of the earthly realm were oddly placed as always. 

“I-I believe that a more beautiful handwriting will win the approval of Schneeuwerik.” Fulke said. 




Sweet sweet Fulke, why did you have to make life so difficult? Eckhart will only be more angered with this nonsense you spit out so brazenly. You already could feel a headache settling in as you rubbed your temples. 




“Really?” Eckhart sputtered. His cheeks were flushed out of anger.




“This revelation had graced me when Lentetulp had given her first blessing and kiss to the earthly realm. The threads had been spun with another time weaver’s apprentice but I heard that the threads of life had not been fully woven yet.” 




You sighed. Fulke really had dug himself a grave here. To think that he would question whether Eckhart was fit to be your retainer while at the same time implying that you had been looking for another apprentice. It was high time that you should intervene, before Eckhart might get some wrong ideas about your intentions. 




However, Eckhart’s eyes lit up. He curled his fingers into fists.




“Tell me more and then our fates are woven together.” Eckhart said. 




You leaned back. Was it not up to you to make have the last say on this? Well, Eckhart seemed to be out of his recent slump, so you will let him have his fun for now. You hoped that he would not beat him up too hard. You didn’t want your parents to yell at you again for not stopping Eckhart’s rampages.




“Your sword dance of last spring is abysmal to look at and doesn’t even resemble the grace of the time weaver and your roughness in the way you carry yourself will frighten people who are of equal footing to you.”




Was Fulke really asking to be beaten up? You threw your hands off this mess and was already thinking about how you should deal with the aftermath. 




To your surprise, both Fulke and Eckhart shook hands in a sense of true camaraderie. It was truly a sight to behold.  Although Eckhart was perhaps squeezing his hand a little too tightly based on Fulke’s pained expression, there were no blows exchanged between them. When you looked at the tutor, he was as struck by this unusual chain of events as you. 




After Eckhart finally let go of the poor boy, Fulke slumped against the wall while clutching tightly to his hand. You stepped out of your desk to check whether it was something worth reporting. With one firm look, Eckhart stepped back so that you could take a proper look. 




You took Fulke’s hand to examine it. Strangely enough, he let you do so without much protest. It looked a little reddened, but it seemed like he was still able to move his fingers. Then your eyes caught the inside of his sleeve. A small piece of fabric was poking out of it. When you lightly tugged at it, you saw the embroidery that was all too familiar to you. 




How did he come to possess your handkerchief? Why did he even have it in the first place? You knew that Fulke probably had underlying reasons to come here just like the tutor, but to think that this was the reason. You must have done something in the past to earn his fixation on you. You closed your eyes and rubbed your temples with your free hand.




No one will have to know, not even Fulke. 




You should leave this out of your report.




Since viscount Grunnenberg had claimed to not be able to teach you anything worthwhile, perhaps you should ask for another tutor. Ah, that would make for a splendid report.

The day when Herafst sung her howling songs to her most treasured sisters Zummerin and Lentetulp, was the day you had first witnessed a death. Of course you heard about the increasing amount of executions for treason, but these people weren’t individuals you knew or really cared about. At some point you knew that you had to succeed your parents and find a proper wife to produce the next heir. 




It was during this dinner, a rarity nowadays, that your parents were about to discuss who your betrothed will be. You had returned from the royal academy just one month ago. Marrying and looking for a girl had not even crossed your mind even though this too was your duty. It honestly felt strange to be twenty now and to be of marriageable age. You still were the same person you were the year before. Nothing should have changed.




The long table with your mother and father sitting at each end of it, was now completely devoid of guests. You were sitting in the middle while you tried to not wander your eyes too far away from them. Your free hand was fumbling with your cape. It felt kind of odd to walk around without your brooch. A few days ago it had somehow vanished along with the feeling that this dinner conversation would ever go well. 




Behind you stood Eckhart whose mind was in a place beyond your scope of comprehension. He was still gazing at his silver necklace with her thread encased in the glowing gemstone as if it was Fransisca herself. You didn’t know how he had managed to get the daughter of the duke of Cassisheit to accept his thread, even though you all were aware of the fact that she favored the arts more than swordplay. You sighed in your head. It was really a miracle come true, for him at least. You really didn't mind if he remained for the rest of his life a bachelor. Perhaps you would have preferred it, but that wouldn't do for Eckhart. It was too bad that Fulke who was visiting his family, couldn’t reign him in this very moment.

You stirred your sweetened porridge while your father and mother took their first bite. They were probably waiting for you to make the first suggestions of possible candidates, but you didn’t care that much. You could trust your parents’ judgement to select someone who would bring the most stability to the kingdom. It would likely be a daughter from a higher ranked duchy who had close ties to your mother’s faction. 




“Is this all you wanted to report?” Your mother said. 




“There were also rumors about Essenschaft introducing clothes with threads made of an unique kind of spinning frame though our apprentice scholars were not able to gather more information in the academy’s dormitory. We have to especially keep close eyes to Lossenhilt as there was movement reported between their duchy’s border gate.”




“A spinning frame?” 




“Indeed mother, with this device one could spin twice, no perhaps four times as fast as a skilled craftsman,”




You knitted your brows. The kingdom still had an upper hand in textiles and pattern weaving, but if knowledge of this spinning frame spread, the threads of the time weaver will be rewoven again. You would have liked to warn your parents beforehand, but letters, even from the future king could be intercepted. 




Your father carefully nodded and folded his hands. “Let us put this matter aside till we have a better understanding how we should proceed next. Have your eyes seen the entangled thread yet?”




You remained silent. If you were to guess what will follow after this twitch in his eyes, you hoped that it would only be a light scolding. Just as you were about to find some hope, he rubbed his temples.




“Didn’t the wet nurse and your other retainers instruct you about the duty of the next bearer of the life thread?”




And that was ensuring the next generation of candidates to the throne, you fool. How could I ever have raised such a sloth? Your mind already filled in the words left unspoken. It was better to have finished this matter in this meeting before Eckhart in his fretted state of panic would induce another headache to you. Let’s see, it had to be someone of a high ranking duchy who had not close ties to Essenschaft or had other questionable loyalties. You glanced back at Eckhart when a certain individual sprung in mind.

“Then shall we pick the duke of Cassisheit’s second daughter?”




Eckhart’s face paled for an odd reason. You tilted your head. It would seem like a well-thought out pick and with her being recently born, your peace and quiet in your quarters will be retained for much longer. 




You then looked at your father and mother for approval, but all of a sudden they both collapsed. From that moment on the time weaver had ceased his work. Ceramic plates and silver cups clattered on the floor. You heard faint footsteps and voices coming from outside. Eckhart gripped your arm so tightly that it would certainly bruise, but you hadn’t felt anything as all your senses were numbed. The plate in front of you stretched and bent under your eyes like a whirling cloud. 




Your parents were fine moments before. They both carried a rosy complexion, had no previous known ailments. Their threads were destined to be long. How could facts and reality be this warped? Then a sharp sting on your cheek brought your thoughts into a standstill.




“Your majesty, please give me your order.”




Eckhart tightened his grip on you while unsheathing his sword. You could tell that he was desperately trying to hold back any curse words or any other foul language by the way he had clenched his teeth. You both turned your heads as you saw the dining room’s door flying open. A flood of guards flooded in the room with the commander and a panting Fulke in the lead.




“There’s a massive attack going on, the duke of Cassisheit. Don’t touch the porri-“




As soon as their eyes locked on the unmoving bodies of your parents, they lowered their heads in shame. When they saw you living and breathing, they all let out a small sigh of relief. However, Eckhart eyes widened the moment the Cassisheit family was mentioned. 




Swallowing down the rising bile in your throat, you tore your gaze away from your parents and raised your hand to stop Eckhart’s upcoming rampage.




“Please let an apt physician examine his majesty’s and her majesty’s pulse.” You shifted your eyes to the commander. “Uncle, please explain your sudden arrival and why Fulke has accompanied you?”




“Your majest-“ 




Your heart twisted and something seemed to have clammed up in your chest.  The commander paused. His eyes flitted towards the place where they had collapsed. His arms which were pressed stiffly against his sides, shook while he gave his report.




“Your royal highness, There was a peasant uprising in the duchy of Cassisheit. They would have held them off, but someone seemed to have supplied them with firearms. They, these wretched people, stormed the mansion. The whole family had come to meet the time weaver.”




 Fulke filled in the rest. “These two incidents seemed to be orchestrated by the same group. From the gathered intel, viscount Grunnenberg and the other nobles whose name we currently do not possess, had planned to assassinate the royal family. The cook and the taste testers had already admitted their guilt.”




He lowered his head before pushing the last sentence out. “My father seemed to also be implicated in this plot.”




Everything had finally sunk in as a heavy weight pooled in your stomach. The future that was once so certain had crumbled within one meal. In your last bout of denial, you clung to the small hope that your parents will wake up and take control with as much grace as they had always done. However, the physician that had just arrived tightly shook his head. Without any words exchanged between you two, you had been forced to accept that your parents had truly left the earthly realm. 




Eckhart too barely held himself together as he tightly clutched to his necklace. For the first time you saw the stubborn yet strong hearted Eckhart shed his tears.




“The cook and the taste testers, we have to bring them here, your majesty”




“Please do.” You said. 




Soon enough the traitors had been brought in. No, that might be too much of an euphemism. They were dragged into the dining room as if they were pigs about to be slaughtered. There were two men, one of which was the head cook and two women who had both served as taste testers for the royal family. They cowered and knelt as you stepped forward to examine them closer. 




You knew that all the royal family’s closest attendants were nobles that had pledged their oath. You tilted your head. You wondered why they had decided to betray you. Was it perhaps due to financial struggles or simply to gather more influence after the status quo had shifted?




“W-we were forced into this, your majesty.”




“Please grant us your mercy, I have no son, my daughter…”




“Forgive us, this was all the fault of the baron.”




“And don’t forget the viscount. He had threatened to maim my family if I didn’t obey.”




Before you could respond to their pleas, one of the attendant’s face had met Eckhart’s boot. A cold fury flashed in his eyes while he dug his heels into the man’s ribs. He briskly turned his head to meet your eyes. His cold voice seemly devoid of any emotion besides contempt and his uncharacteristically soft spoken words sent shivers to even the most hardened guards in the room.

“Your majesty, oath breakers do not deserve your mercy. It would be recommended to commence their execution.”




You closed your eyes. All the roaring emotions raging inside of you were shoved into a tiny box and closed with a lid. You had to act as the ruler now. The life thread was now yours to protect. The young and carefree prince Henrik, who was determined to choose the path with the least headaches, had no right to exist anymore. Your eyes opened as you had accepted your new mantle.

Fulke had all this time been looking at you with teary eyes. He did say that his father had also played a role in your parents' and the Cassisheit family’s death. If you were to give a harsh punishment to these attendants, one couldn’t show sudden mercy to a lowly baron, especially when the oath breakers' families were all of a higher standing. 




The commander had all this time been silent. With one glance you could tell that he was waiting for your answer.

“Have them all be relieved from their duty and place them under house arrest. Assign your most trusted guards to keep watch over them.”




You didn’t want any blood to spill. There was also the fact that you wanted to pry every single piece of information out of them while preventing them communicating to other nobles involved in this plot. Dead men sadly couldn’t speak. A lot more people were behind this scheme. Based on the enormous web of contacts that had been spun,  the ring leader must be someone with quite a huge amount of influence and authority, someone with as much influence as a duke. 




“As you command.” The commander knelt and left the room with all the guards gathered here. The oath breakers followed them, now bound with a rope. The last ones to leave were the bodies of your parents, now wrapped in a table cloth to preserve their modesty. The only occupants of the room were you, Fulke and Eckhart. 




As soon as you tried to think of ways to calm Eckhart down, he unleashed his full fury on you. 




“How could you, how could you fucking do this? They killed your damn parents and now you're treating them like your guests? Have you gone mad?”




Something in you just broke. There was no one you had to keep up appearances to. You two could talk like you used to do before any roles were enforced on you, back when he was just your older brother. It wasn't proper to show such a weakness to others, especially to people that relied on you. However, you couldn't keep your words from wavering.




“Eckhart, please.”




He closed his eyes and breathed in deeply. “I, I need to be alone, think a little.”




In other circumstances, it would be tremendously amusing that Eckhart voluntarily offered to use his head for once. It would be such a feat that even the timid Fulke would pester him for days about it. Now, it only made the feeling even more bitter when the door slammed shut.




You sighed and slumped back into your chair. Despite the fact you hadn't done that much besides sitting around and talking, every part of your body ached. Your eyelids felt heavy. Was this even the right decision?. You cocked your head to Fulke. The whole time he had kept quiet.




“How much of a blunder have I made during my first day as king?”




“Eckhart is a person who needs to get things out of his mind by means of physical activity. He will set his priorities straight soon enough.” Fulke said. 




Why did he always have such a way of words? Did he pity you enough that he tried to spare your feelings and dodge your question? Everything was in shambles in your head. You let out a dry laugh.




“So I should have executed your father.”




“That would be a choice a normal king would make, a laudable choice even considering these particular chain of events.” He said. A small smile traced his lips.  




“My former master had summoned my father a few days ago. It appeared that my father had been quite stricken by the contents of his letter and I admit that I had taken a peak at its contents too without his expressed permission. After that I had decided to motivate some of our family’s attendants a little so that they paid closer attention to his words. The royal family was mentioned and a certain kind of porridge. There was sadly not enough time for me to intervene.”




It was quite callous of Fulke to be so calculating towards his former master, but you were glad that Fulke’s loyalty to you was higher than him. One wouldn’t want to earn Fulke’s wrath. Eckhart had once claimed that you were the one who had corrupted the poor boy, but in your opinion he was already full of poison. Without you ever instructing him, he had not only used your wetnurse who was also Eckhart's mother to keep him in line whenever he tried to escape their study sessions and later on he had somehow managed Eckhart's tutor in swordsmanship to bar Eckhart from training if he wasn't progressing as fast as he should. 




Fulke slid his wrist into the inside of his coat. Low and behold, your lost golden brooch now was clasped in his hand. 




“Well, I had to decide my next course of action as quickly as possible. I went straight to the commander's room using your brooch as proof that this was an urgent matter that ought to not be ignored. I convinced him to send some guards to fetch the cook and the taste testers as there was a high likelihood that they would have been bribed by my father. If they were caught before the dishes were served, then this crises was averted. To my dismay, this incompetent waste of space had managed to succeed for once. Ah, it would be more than satisfactory to see their eyes of despair as their whole future is snipped away.”




His eyes sparkled with a fevered shine as if he was a blushing maiden. He intertwined his fingers together while he dreamily laid his cheeks on the back of his hands. 




This was actually the first time you saw him like this. When he was with you, he was a lot more quiet, timid, a little panicky and twitchy like a small rodent. In the beginning and even until now you thought that Eckhart had exaggerated the stories about Fulke. Perhaps they were true after all. You didn't really want to ask why he had stolen your brooch in the first place as he had only known of this summoning after he had taken his leave. 




“Shouldn't you be angry that I hadn't done so?” You said.




Fulke leant back to the dinner table. He lightly hummed a soft tune. The corners of his eyes wrinkled a little.




“You saved my father, how could I possibly be upset? He may have not have been spun from the thickest thread, but I know he considers me to be his Lentetulp. Without him, a child born out of wedlock would be quietly disposed of as the other members of my family would always gladly like to remind me. My father… he is the only one….. I'm unable to discard him and him me.”




“Even after you publicly opposed him?”




He frowned and said. “One says that although the three siblings carried a grudge towards Schneeuwerik due to her being the reason for the eternal continuation of their punishment, they still called her their little sister.”




“I see.”




He shuffled closer to you and carefully placed the brooch on your palms. His warm fingertips grazed your skin.




“There's no one in the room. Everything that happens within these walls stays with you and me.”




Seeing the gemstone, the only thing your parents had personally gifted to you, lying in the palm of your hand, made your stomach twist in knots. You heard his soft yelp when you rested your head against his shoulder. At first you felt nothing, but as you felt his warmth the lid of bottled feelings sprung open when you realized what you had truly lost. This future where your mother lavished praises to you while your father nodded in approval, no, where they embraced you telling that everything will be fine, was a future that wasn't likely to happen if at all. However, the fact that the possibility of this ever happening was ripped away from you so suddenly, made you want to grieve for the times that had never existed.




“Will Eckhart leave me?” You whispered.




“You know that he can't.” Fulke then paused. “I think you should also think a little more yourself.”




“I don't understand.”




“Then I know that you will come up with something good, seeing that you are the furthest thing from conventional as one can be, but that is precisely the reason why many people want to serve you and are concerned about your future and wellbeing.”




The following day, Eckhart came back just as Fulke had said. He had acted like nothing had happened, as if nothing had changed between the two of you. Even when you two were in the study where the thick wall shielded the words exchanged in the room, the stony face of professionalism hadn't softened in the slightest amount.




You gave him a tight smile before unclasping your brooch from your cape. Eckhart's eyes widened as you pinned it under his one. Ah, good to see that he was already becoming more like Eckhart.




“This, please keep it safe as my milk sibling. The stone will accompany you at night.”




“I can't accept this, I'm not worthy of such trust after I had questioned your judgement and done….”




“You still decided to come back to keep me from wreaking havoc in the palace or to remind me of my duties, am I not correct to take this as a fact?” 




Eckhart's eyes hardened. With heavily furrowed brows he knelt in front of you.




“What use does an older brother have if he cannot protect his little brother?” he said while slowly curving up his lips.

“Have them all be executed as swiftly as possible with the highest possible dishonor.” 




This was what one had to do when someone committed treason. Your ancestors, even the first king of the nation who was wildly beloved by his subjects, had to quell an insurrection or two during his time. If you were to punish them lightly, your future authority may be questioned in the future. A possible weakness of you will be revealed, something that would put you at a great disadvantage.  The commander had seemed to come to the same conclusion as you as he curtly nodded.




“As you wish.”




After you had spoken your verdict the oath breakers lost their last bit of restraint. Some of them were crying, the cook was outright screaming when the guards forced them to line up. With the sharp edge of their swords they shaved off all of their hair. Then they wrung their brooches and capes out of them. The family stones were smashed into tiny fragments while their capes were torn to shreds. 




Once they were done, they kicked the head cook forward so that his face remained planted on the floor. He only stopped crying when a sword was thrust inside his chest. The other remaining oath breakers watched in horror as blood frothed out of the man's mouth before he collapsed soon afterwards. You tilted your head. There were now three people left. Their cries grew weaker and weaker as the executions were carried out till the last one, a woman who looked like she had just completed her coming of age ceremony, was released from her duty.




You scrunched up your nose. The stale air of rust bristled against the back of your neck. It wasn't your first execution. One year before you became an adult you had witnessed your parents ordering the same thing. In their case it was a captain who had apparently sneaked in vital information about the king and queen to Essenschaft. At that time, it hadn't bothered you this much except for the foul odor that hung in the courtyard corridors for days. 




You looked at the bodies that had now been thrown in a single pile. Blood pooled underneath them. Their dark red color stained the wooden planks. You swallowed down the bile that had been building up inside you. Now that you were the one issuing this order, you finally knew that this was quite different.




Although the most painful part of the execution was over, the process was considered to be incomplete without the grand parade. Until that was done, it was customary that their bodies will not be buried yet. Their disgraced corpses will be paraded down the streets to show others the outcome when one's loyalty to the king wavered. 




Once they made sure that no one was breathing, the guards hauled up their bodies and left to prepare for tomorrow's festivities. The commander had ordered the remaining soldiers to wrap your parents' bodies with the table cloth and carefully carried them out of the dining room. Before he closed the door, he gave one sympathetic glance to Fulke and you.




When the soft click of the knob became a sound from the distant past, the only people that were left in the dining room were you, Eckhart and Fulke.




“I have to attend to some family matters.” He said after he closed his eyes.




“Look, Fulke it had to be do-.”




“Please, your majesty, I respect your judgement and your reasoning. It was honestly a commendable action you took, but I need to notify the other members of my house and discuss how to proceed.” He sighed before continuing. “I will come back next day, forgive me.”




You knew that this was bound to happen, but the way he expressed his words so coldly made your chest sting a little. Eckhart rushed forward and grabbed Fulke by his collar.




“Didn’t you fucking swear to your oath? While you are running away to hide in your little family shack, his majesty will be dealing with the full fallout tomorrow. Your life, my life, they don't matter as long as Henrik remains safe.”




“And Fransisca's life, can you throw her away if this were to benefit his majesty?”




A vein in his forehead popped. Eckhart glared at him as he said the following in a low voice. “Don't speak about her like that.”

Fulke gave him a small smile.




“See, your answer is all too clear.” 




He then turned away from Eckhart who seemed to have been frozen into place and rested his eyes on you. Swiftly closing the distance between you two, he slipped your long lost brooch in your coat pocket.




“I'll take my leave.” He said.




 The dining room remained oddly quiet for a while after Fulke had left. Not wanting to leave the room just yet, you slumped back to your chair. The untouched porridge in front of you had stiffened. You were the one who broke the silence.




“Is what Fulke had said true?”




“My life is yours to command.” He said with a stony face. 




Your eyes wandered off to his hands which were quivering under Herafst' autumn air. Eckhart was never a born master of deception. If there was a secret to hide or someone who tried to pry information out of his mouth, he would simply not speak. The way how he carried his emotions under his sleeve, made him not really suitable to gather intel. However, it did make you want to lower your guard to him just a little more as his rather crude way of showing his emotions put you more at ease than any carefully thought out noblelike response. 




Your hands tightly wound themselves around your brooch that had at last returned to your side. Slowly you shuffled closer to him. You saw his eyes widen ever so slightly when you pinned it underneath his own.




“It was lost.” He sputtered out.




You shrugged while tilting your head. Fulke had indeed been very careful about it or Eckhart was really that obvious about everything that didn't concern his guard duties. You blinked. It was probably both. The question how Fulke had even come to possess your brooch briefly flitted in your mind before you focused your attention back to Eckhart. There were more important things to deal with.




“Eckhart, please keep it safe as my milk sibling.”




The person in question looked at the brooch and then at you. His mouth hung wide open as you could visibly see him parse out what had just happened.




“I had just told you that-"




Before he could spout more nonsense, you held up your hand.




“How many times did I have to see you talk about how beautiful Fransisca is, how nice she smells, how her voice rang like the temple bells and so on. Any dim witted individual would have known by now that she is your Schneeuwerik.” 




To emphasize you point, you pressed your index finger on his forehead. 




“If I had wanted this liability to be gone, I would have done so the moment you had announced your engagement, no?”




Eckhart swallowed. You tilted your head. Hadn't this thought ever crossed his mind before? You thought a little harder. The answer was that he probably hadn't done so, because that action would require him to think for an extra moment. Sweet, sweet Eckhart, causing headaches for you even during these grave times.




“There's no one here. In this room we are only brothers, Henrik and his insufferable brother Eckhart.”




You gasped as Eckhart pulled you into a bear hug. His wet cheeks were pressed on the crook of your neck. Humming a gentle tune, you patted him on his back like a parent consoling their child. Feeling his warm arms reminded you of memories that had never existed. Times where you and your mother walked hand in hand or where your father ruffled your hair while he lathered his praise to you. Although these dreams seemed so far out of reach before this day where the time weaver ceased to spin his threads, you couldn't help but mourn that the possibility of this mirage ever becoming reality had been crushed before your eyes. 


At some point along the way you didn't know whose tears had dampened your cravat.




The following day, Fulke had come back as promised. When asked if everything was sorted out, he gave you a thin polite smile. Only months later you had heard that the baron’s family was found floating in the river.
