action_results.result:
Winter, a time where Schneeuwerik’s tears formed the raging blizzards and her misery covered the planes in thick layers of snow, was usually the time where everyone huddled together to avert the goddess’ haunted wails.  One could only pray that Lentetulp will soon arrive with her other siblings as the time weaver unwound his threads yet again. 




You rubbed your hands together after you had signed one document after the other. Most of them dealt with trade matters, military matters and infrastructure. Putting your seal on these pieces of paper, was only a formality. All of the actual discussions on future policies happened behind close doors as long as the people involved were able to travel to the palace. It was more efficient this way, letting people speak out to their heart's contents and hear them argue their points. The written word was a miraculous invention, but it lacked the nuance needed to parse out a person's true intentions.




It was still odd to be working in your late father's study. You placed the pen's nib into the ink vial, making sure to not spill a single drop on his dark wooden desk. Although it had already been two years after your parents' untimely arrival at the realm of the gods, your chest still ached whenever you took your seat in your father's chair or used his cup. 




Every object seemed to be in the wrong place, color and shape in this room. The desk should have been a light yellowish color that stood so low that your knees were constantly bumping on the wood. The wooden walls should have been left bare and not fully covered in a wealth of tapestry. While your old study could just barely fit in four people comfortably within its borders, your father's office was twice as big with twice as many chairs. Whereas the study lacked any isolation or heat source, making it cruelly cold in the winter and unbearably hot in the summer, this office felt almost too comfortable to you with its grand hearth placed on your left.




The utter unwelcomeness made you feel as if the room was straight up telling you that you were a foreigner to this land. 

You looked up to see your guard Eckhart sitting in his usual spot near the window, furrowing his brows over his own pile of letters. Although he had refused the offer to rule over Cassisheit as the new duke, he still kept close ties to the region, exchanging letters with the current ruler every month or so. Although you and your advisor Fulke were happy that Eckhart was finally doing paperwork without the need for either of you to threaten or bribe him, you both had to admit that this extra thinking work had by now fried his mind. It was probably very disheartening for him to see such a high ranking duchy fall to grace within only one year despite one's highest efforts to keep things afloat.




“Permit, building, road, army.” 




He mumbled. Sweat dripped from his forehead as his clammy hands jotted down things that were supposed to resemble words which became even more indecipherable as time went by. 




“His majesty, fried fish, sleep, chicken, spring, oh dear gods.” He mumbled.




It wasn't only Eckhart who was working on the brink of collapse, Fulke had not been looking well either. His natural spindly body was now almost skeletal. In certain parts of his joints you can see his skin stretching over his bones. His eyes scoured over the newspaper headlines to look for anything out of the ordinary while his trembling hand barely kept the liquid inside his cup.




“As expected, the multi-spindle spinning frame has now spread all over Essenschaft. The new stream of threads will lower the costs of textiles made there. I wonder if our workshops can keep it up.” 




He furrowed his brows as he sipped on his tea. 




“Let's see what I have to do next. Yes, indeed, check Fulke's handwriting, fish out any grammatical errors and make him rewrite the letter again. I shall make plans how to motivate him next time if he decides to lengthen his break.”




Poor Fulke was following Eckhart's lead. You cradled your head as you saw your two most trusted retainers slowly fall into their own kind of madness. As for you, you had to keep your eyes close to the duke of Lossenhilt. Last year you had done some digging through old documents and mailing lists and found out that this duchy where the captain whom your parents had executed years ago hailed from, had exchanged a suspiciously large amount of letters to Essenschaft. This was all still sheer speculation, but it seemed that the man behind Grunnenberg's orchestrated attacks on the duchy of Cassisheit and the royal family was none other than Lossenhilt. You placed your hands on your hand on your cheek. 




Sadly enough viscount Grunnenberg was found dead in his room a few days after that certain incident. Fulke said that the reports claimed that it was due to alcohol poisoning, but in the short time you had spoke to him, you felt that Grunnenberg didn't seem like a man to overly indulge himself in bottles of wine. Fulke had also agreed with you. 




Despite all those threads coming together like this, there was no good pin to hold them all together. Due to Lossenhilt's size and huge influence, you couldn't just quietly quicken the duke’s year of retirement. There had to be at least a smidge of evidence, something potent enough to tarnish the duke's reputation and weaken his supporters.




Fulke said that the new generation of future nobles had opted to spend their time in these so-called parlor rooms instead of gardens and courtyards where tea parties were held. Most of them offered enriching substances for the mind and a wealth of Zummerin's water imported from the southern duchies. A lot of writers, artists and philosophers gathered there as well, making this a hotspot for the latest trends and ideas. You narrowed your eyes as you sunk into deeper thoughts. If you planted a tiny rumor about the duke in these smoke-filled drug dens and pass on some high quality wine bottles, then it would surely spread like wildfire.




Just as you were about to relay this idea to Fulke to test whether it held up under his scrutiny, your eyes snapped back to the door. Someone was knocking. It took only a few moments for your mind to catch up with the present day. Fulke frequently gathered intel in these parlor rooms and had a few weeks ago told you that he had planned to invite a regular to the palace. Uncharacteristically of him, he had kept the details vague and refused to elaborate on them further when questioned.




“Eckhart, please open the door to greet our guest.” You said.




He only reacted the second time you repeated your request. After some papers that taken flight during Eckhart's mind's awakening were gathered again in a neat pile, Eckhart swiftly shifted into his stony face of cold professionalism and opened the door. 




You blinked again to make sure that you were indeed seeing what you saw. A young woman had indeed entered the room. Seeing that she lacked a cape and family brooch, you concluded that she must be of commoner origins despite her tidy appearance. She kept her bag made out of straw close to her chest, treating its contents as if it was a newborn infant. With anxious eyes similar to a small rodent she looked at Fulke for help. To the woman's relief, Fulke answered her silent plea with a polite smile.




“This is the Merle I was referring to. A former smith’s assistant, she had worked together with a carpenter to produce quite a fascinating invention. One prototype had already been built. Lately she was frequenting the parlor rooms to gather more funding.”


He said while gesturing at her. “Please let us see your work.”




The woman hurriedly nodded and fished out the papers from her bag. With quick, but small steps she handed them over to you. Most of them were drawings with some faint charcoal notes scribbled in the corners. Although the notes were faded so much that you weren't able to read them anymore, you knew simply by looking at the pictures that this was quite something. There was a giant wheel attached to it and a set of metal pistons that were supposed to be moving inside a cylinder.




“May I ask what this device can do?”




“I-It's a machine that runs with steam, your majesty. You burn charcoal inside the furnace and boil water in it. This smoke will rise up and cause this wheel to spin. If you attach all kinds of stuff to it with some screws and bolts, you can make things move without you even lifting a finger. You can use it in any season unlike a water wheel or a wind mill.”




At first she had sounded unsure, but as she continued to talk you could see her eyes sparkling in the same way the professors of the royal academy talked about their field of study. Any formalities she once carefully kept up out of fear were now thrown out of the window. 




“I’m currently seeking for patrons and then I was asking Fulke about it. It turns out that you too are pretty interested in my darling. Will you become my patron?”




You quickly shot a glare at Fulke who straight up pretended that you didn't exist. This was so frustrating. You could already feel that this was going to be massive headache at the end no matter what you chose to do. 




No one seemed to want to make the decision for you as the last person that could possibly give you a way escape this mess, the person who goes by the name of Eckhart, had by now returned to his paperwork. You squeezed your eyes shut and rubbed your temples to banish his mumblings out of your head.




It was time to make your decision now.

With the kingdom still yet to be fully stabilized, you felt that it was unwise to bring in even more trouble. If this machine could truly do everything she had imagined, wouldn't this cause the collapse of nearly every textile workshop and other industries you hadn't even thought of. No, it was too dangerous to invest in this device. Perhaps in the far future you will consider to look at this a second time, but now the only thing you could do was gently refuse her.




“I'm saddened to see that the ends of our threads were sadly not woven together by the time weaver.” You calmly said while donning a pleasant smile. 




Merle furrowed her brows and rubbed her chin. She didn't seem to want to leave yet. Was there something else she had to say? Fulke sighed, walked over to her and whispered something in her ear. Her eyes widened for a brief moment before it settled on a exasperated sigh and tired smile. With her back slumped she gathered her drawings and left the study without even saying brief words of farewell.




An awkward tension hung over the room. There was a lot Fulke had to explain to you and Fulke knew this as well. You two glared daggers at each other, daring the other to give up first. The silence was only interspersed with Eckhart's groans and the sound of pens scratching on sheets of paper. It was ultimately Eckhart that forced you two into a truce. 




“I give up, it's too hard. Fulke can you look at it for a brief mo-" 




His mouth hung open as he looked at you and then at Fulke. His dumbfounded expression quickly shifted into a mischievous smirk. He puffed out his chest.




“Now, now, is this a little spat I see? Fulke, Henrik, just spit it out, tell each other your true feelings and all. It cannot be this hard.”

You reluctantly looked at Fulke. The moment you met his eyes, he promptly looked away. You then cocked your head in Fulke's direction while focusing your attention back to Eckhart. See, this can indeed be this hard. 




“Come on, my head really hurts. Why was that commoner girl here in the first place?” He said. 




Had he really missed the entire conversation? The mind was truly a marvelous thing. You quickly informed him of everything you knew about her and the significance of Fulke not communicating many things properly to you. 




“You see, these trade agreements cannot be signed with one single hand wave and Fulke knows it too. If we were to suddenly announce it, we would face a lot of resistance from the workshops and perhaps some duchies that have an economy with a heavy focus on weaving. We have to lay all the necessary groundwork before we can proceed.”




Fulke covered his face with his hand. 




“I wasn't sure if you would outright refuse to meet her considering her commoner background. Then there is the fact that we need to quickly secure her before other nobles will steal her away. As far as I know, she is the only one that knows the entire inner workings of the machine. We need to set up her contract as fast as possible with as few people listening in. The best time was during winter, this day actually.”




“Still, you knew that this is not the right time to introduce revolutionary inventions, especially without properly consulting me first.” You said.




A brief flash of cold fury flashed in his eyes. He coolly walked to your desk and leant forward. The slight tilt of his head looked almost innocent except for the broad smile that slathered every word of his in chilly poison.




“The information dear Merle possessed cannot fall in hands of Essenschaft. It was either to bring her under our wings or to resort to more conventional measures.” His fingers lightly tapped on the desk. “I had hoped for the former as I was quite fond of her and her family. If my memories didn't betray me, the carpenter was her fiancé, no?”




You accepted his challenge as you met his unblinking eyes. 




“It would be easy for such a resourceful person like you to take care of this matter?”




“I will not be swayed by mere flattery.” He said. “You have dug this hole yourself. I will not bloody my hand due to your incompetence.”




Seeing that this called for reinforcements you flashed a smile at Eckhart who had by now had willingly retired himself from the battlefield. He surely wouldn't mind if you forcibly dragged him back.  




“Say Eckhart, do you mind to guide Fulke gently so that he can see the errors of his ways?”




Eckhart remained silent. You broadened your smile.




“I'll do your paperwork in exchange.”




Immediately a new flash of determination replaced the dim look in his eyes. He unclasped the brooch you had given him and dangled it in front of Fulke who longingly stared at the glimmering jewel. 




“You can keep this for an entire day if you help Henrik with his work.”




Fulke spoke without any hesitation. “It's a deal.”




The following month Fulke quietly reported that Merle and her fiancé sadly had taken their leave to the realm of the gods. In a tiny section at the far back of the newspaper was reported that a couple had fallen from the bridge and tragically drowned in the river after they went out drinking to celebrate their upcoming wedding.

While the kingdom was not fully stabilized yet, this opportunity will solve many of your current problems at once. You only had to fully monopolize Merle and her invention. It will be a lot of work for all of you, but Fulke would probably not mind as he was the one who invited her in the first place. There was also a small childish part in you that wanted to see the machine in full action. You wondered how it would look beyond the restrictions of its drawings. 




Due to your excitement building up inside of you, you almost forgot to maintain your public persona as you were about to spring up from your chair. You closed your eyes and quickly forced yourself to regain your composure.




“It seemed that the time weaver had made the ends of our threads forge together during his blessing.”




Merle furrowed her brows and rubbed her chin. She didn't seem to be that excited about her offer. Was there something else she had to say or did she want more time to think things through? Fulke chuckled, walked over to her and whispered something in her ear. Her eyes widened for a brief moment before she started to smile as if the time weaver himself had showed up to unwind his threads in front of her. Tears of utmost joy sprung from her as her body swayed back and forth out of dizzying excitement. 




“Thank you, your majesty, you're such a lifesaver. I'll do my best to make the best machine possible. I hope to not disappoint you.” 

She loudly proclaimed as she danced around the room. Her skirt fluttered when she spun around. The loudness of her voice was so jarring to her previously shown persona, that even Eckhart was torn from his work. His dazed eyes quickly sharpened as he reflexively reached out for his sword. It was only due to Fulke's intervention, that he had not pressed the tip of blade against her neck.




“Ah, Merle that's enough for now. Don't want you to pass out and all.  I’ll meet ya tomorrow at the Blue Weavel around the usual time to get your contract sorted.” Fulke said. 




You blinked and checked your ears if you had indeed heard such crass words coming from Fulke, the person Eckhart had teased for being even more fond of using theological euphemisms than you. Thus it was really a sight to behold to see the polite Fulke swear like a craftsman while dragging Merle to the exit. You tilted you head. At least that poisonous smile of his never went away. 




When Merle had left the office and Fulke had returned with an even more haggard appearance than he had before, you immediately jumped into business matters. Rest could always come later and it was actually Fulke had brought this to himself in the first place. 




Just as Eckhart was about to retreat to his papers, you forcibly pulled him back with a smile.




“Dear Fulke, it seems like you owe me and Eckhart a proper explanation for this rather unconventional way of setting up new exclusive contracts. I do understand why you want to monopolize the manufacturing of this machine as its versatile use can prove to be a vital weapon to strengthen our economy.”




You broadened your smile as you continued. Eckhart nodded along with you.




“You see, these contracts cannot be signed with one single hand wave. If we were to suddenly announce it, we would face a lot of resistance from the workshops and perhaps some duchies whose economies relied upon their weaving. We have to lay all the necessary groundwork before we can properly proceed.”




Fulke let out a exasperated smile. Although the tiredness in his eyes was all too apparent, there was an odd softness to him that was rare to see. 




“The information dear Merle possessed cannot fall in hands of Essenschaft. It was either to bring her under our wings or to resort to more conventional measures. The poor woman is more trouble than she is worth, but she looked so happy when she told me about her engagement with her childhood friend and then she had dragged me all the way through the city to introduce me to her family.” 




Eckhart furrowed his brows. One could almost see every small cog move inside his mind as he tried to form his own opinion on the matter. He then looked at the drawings Merle had left behind and slowly shook his head. 




“I don't know if this is a really good idea. A contract would not stop other nobles from simply neutralizing her. There is also the risk that some duke will kidnap her family and force her to tell her reveal everything.” He said.




You knew that Eckhart had wanted to say that it was better to dispose of her first before any information is leaked to others. Fulke gave him a wry smile.




“I'll take full responsibility of this venture and I will take care of your paperwork for this day.”




When Eckhart still didn't look that convinced, Fulke cocked his head. He said the following words without blinking a single moment.




“If you agree to let me prepare a contract for her, I will make sure that the duchy of Cassisheit will have exclusive rights for the machine for two years.”




Fulke's gaze intensified while Fulke broadened his poisonous smile. Without exchanging a single word the two shook on the deal. You carefully chose not to disclose to Eckhart the fact that Fulke had probably already planned to do these two things in the first place if you agreed to take Merle under your wing. Even the most cruelest part in you wouldn't want to crush the twinkles in Eckhart’s eyes. 




Thus you let him enjoy his oh so brief vacation and bathe in this temporary happiness. Ignorance was a weakness for many, but in Eckhart's case it might as well be his strength. You hummed as you finished your own paperwork.

And what may that be? The beginning of a new era or the continuation of the status quo? Will you strive to listen to the insurrectionists and continue to let the time weaver spin his threads or will you fight to keep the kingdom you had dearly loved?


You muttered as your fingertips touched the doorknob.
